title.text: Neural Networks and Spelling Features for Native Language Identification

abstractContent.text: We present the RUG-SU team's submission at the Native Language Identification Shared Task 2017.

We combine several approaches into an ensemble, based on spelling error features, a simple neural network using word representations, a deep residual network using word and character features, and a system based on a recurrent neural network.
Our best system is an ensemble of neural networks, reaching an F1 score of 0.8323.
Although our system is not the highest ranking one, we do outper-form the baseline by far.

introductionContent.text: Native Language Identification (NLI) is the task of identifying the native language of, e.g., the writer of an English text.

entities.text: Native Language Identification (NLI) is the task of identifying the native language of, e.g., the writer of an English text

introductionContent.text: In this paper, we describe the University of Groningen / Stockholm University (team RUG-SU) submission to NLI Shared Task 2017 ( . Neural networks constitute one of the most popular methods in natural language processing these days, but appear not to have been previously used for NLI.
Our goal in this paper is therefore twofold.
On the one hand, we wish to investigate how well a neural system can perform the task.
On the other hand, we wish to investigate the effect of using features based on spelling errors.
